reasoning: The critique mainly flags implicit assumptions (possibility of meaningful moral trade, coherence of a “correct view” under antirealism, feasibility of binding commitments, and the “narrow target” picture). These are fairly central to the essay’s optimism-via-trade and its framing of convergence, so centrality is moderate-high. However, it doesn’t supply object-level arguments that these assumptions are false or unlikely; it mostly labels dependencies/hidden load, so it only weakly undermines the position (low strength). The flagged assumptions are generally plausible as genuine background dependencies, so correctness is high. It is understandable but schematic and underspecified (e.g., how each hidden assumption materially changes the conclusion), hence moderate clarity. Little is purely irrelevant, but some of the “dependencies” section reads more like a map than a critique, giving modest dead weight. It raises multiple independent issues rather than pressing a single line of attack. Overall impact on the position is small.
title: Broad moral convergence scenarios deserve greater decision weight than assumed
